summary: Eating later in the evening is associated with reduced glucose tolerance and altered circadian rhythm markers. Regular meal timing is associated with more stable energy and appetite regulation.
observed_patterns: Late first meal → afternoon energy dip
implication_logic: If dinner is frequently late, next-morning energy may feel flatter. If first meal is delayed, afternoon focus often dips.
intervention_leverage: Shift last meal earlier rather than reducing calories. Earlier first fuel often stabilizes energy more than larger portions later.

references.title: Meal Timing Regulates the Human Circadian System

summary: Mild dehydration is associated with decreased alertness and increased fatigue perception. Hydration timing matters: proactive intake earlier in the day is often associated with more stable afternoon energy.
observed_patterns: Delayed hydration → reactive rather than preventive
implication_logic: If hydration is low or delayed, perceived fatigue may increase even without sleep deficit.
intervention_leverage: Improve hydration earlier in the day. Timing may matter more than quantity.

summary: Stress alters appetite patterns and digestive comfort. High stress may reduce or increase appetite; heavy meals during stress may feel uncomfortable.
observed_patterns: High stress → appetite drop or irregularity
Light, easy meals → often better tolerated on high-stress days
implication_logic: If stress is high and appetite is low, forcing volume may add load. Small, easy meals and hydration often help more.
intervention_leverage: One small meal or snack and hydration earlier. No pressure on amount.

summary: Post-exercise and overload contexts (poor sleep, travel, late night) benefit from timing and hydration over volume. Delayed nutrition after training may increase next-day fatigue.
observed_patterns: Gym day → timing and hydration matter more than volume
Party night → lighter meal and hydration support next-day energy
Poor sleep + stress → earlier last meal and hydration help
implication_logic: If recovery demand is high, prioritize timing and hydration rather than optimizing meal size or macros.
intervention_leverage: Prioritize one pre-event meal and hydration; keep late meal lighter to support sleep and tomorrow's energy.

summary: Protein at meals is associated with more stable satiety and fewer sharp hunger swings. Skipping or very low protein may increase appetite variability. No gram targets; focus on pattern.
observed_patterns: Protein at meals → more stable satiety
Skipping breakfast protein → appetite swings later
Balanced meals → more stable energy than extremes
implication_logic: If under-fueled or appetite is swinging, earlier fuel with some protein often helps more than increasing portion size later.
intervention_leverage: Earlier fuel with balanced meal; consistency and timing matter more than optimizing single nutrients.
